awd_titl_txt: Conference: 34th  Midwestern Conference on Combinatorics and Combinatorial Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for participation by junior researchers, graduate students, undergraduates, and high school teachers in the 34th Midwestern Conference on Combinatorics and Combinatorial Computing (MCCCC34), which will be held at Illinois State University in Normal, Illinois, on October 21-23, 2022. The MCCCC began as the Carbondale Combinatorics Conferences which were held (1986-1990) at Southern Illinois University in Carbondale. The conference has since evolved into a prestigious national conference in all areas of combinatorics and combinatorial computing. It has achieved recognition and attracted scholars and researchers of various backgrounds from national and international institutions. A recent trend in the MCCCC series is the increased participation of graduate and undergraduate student researchers. The conference will feature 6 principal 50-minute speakers and about 60 contributed 20-minute talks by participants from throughout the nation and other parts of the world. We estimate around 100 participants will attend. The selection process for funding support will prioritize women, members of underrepresented groups, people with disabilities, veterans, and students. The Conference is supported in part by Illinois State University and by the Institute for Combinatorics and its Applications.

After a 2-year hiatus due to the pandemic, we aim to nurture and expand the opportunities at the MCCCC34 by making mathematics research more accessible and inclusive, and emphasizing recruitment and support for both graduate and undergraduate students. MCCCC34 will cover a spectrum of pure and applied combinatorics, including graph theory, design theory, enumeration, and combinatorial computing. The conference will provide a conducive atmosphere for research mathematicians, graduate students, undergraduate students, and others interested in combinatorics and combinatorial computing to explore and discuss a variety of research problems in these areas, particularly problems that have a connection to both areas.  The conference organizers aim to publish the conference proceedings in a research journal. The conference website can be found at: https://about.illinoisstate.edu/mcccc34/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 34th Midwestern Conference on Combinatorics and Combinatorial Computing was held at Illinois State University in Normal, Illinois from Friday, October 21 to Sunday, October 23, 2022. All conference activities took place on ISU's campus in the State Farm Hall of Business. The conference was organized by the principal investigators Amin Bahmanian, Mike Plantholt, and Songling Shan from Illinois State University, along with Ryan Bunge, Craig Cullen, and Papa Sissokho from the same institution, Heather Jordon (Mathematics Reviews), and Dan Roberts (Illinois Wesleyan University).

 

The conference covered various aspects of pure and applied combinatorics, including graph theory, design theory, enumeration, and combinatorial computing. A total of 96 participants registered for the conference, with over 87 attendees present according to the sign-up sheet. Among the participants were one high school student, two high school mathematics teachers, and more than 10 undergraduate students. The conference featured six plenary talks delivered by esteemed speakers: Brian Alspach from the University of Newcastle, Australia (delivered virtually), Marijn Heule from Carnegie Mellon University, USA, Mariusz Meszka from AGH University of Science and Technology, Poland, Anita Pasotti from the University of Brescia, Italy, Wannasiri Wannasit from Chiang Mai University, Thailand, and Anna Weigandt from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, USA.

 

Additionally, there were 48 twenty-minute talks by various speakers (three talks were canceled due to speaker absences), totaling more than 60 speakers. Talks given by REU students were often presented by two individuals. On Friday and Sunday, the talks were divided into two parallel sessions, while on Saturday, there were three parallel sessions. The conference provided an opportunity to submit papers to "Springer Proceedings in Mathematics & Statistics," and a total of 17 papers were submitted. Currently, the papers are undergoing the review process. The conference was highly successful and particularly highlighted the research work of past REU participants.

 

Most of the National Science Foundation (NSF) funding provided travel support to participants who applied for assistance through an application process. A total of 28 individuals received support, including one high school student, seven undergraduate students, and 13 graduate students. The NSF funding also covered some of the expenses for the plenary speakers. For more information about the conference, including the schedule and abstracts of talks, please visit the conference website at https://about.illinoisstate.edu/mcccc34/. The website's "Schedule" section outlines the program and provides clickable links to abstracts and, in some cases, the voluntarily submitted talk slides by the speakers.

 


Last Modified: 05/23/2023
Modified by: Songling Shan
